learning_outcomes.description: Describe the core philosophical values, principles, conceptual underpinnings, strategies and approaches of public health
Apply principles of equity, diversity and inclusion to contemporary public health challenges within the context of current and future action
Critically reflect on the history, context and different ways of knowing in public health and consider how these have influenced public health action
Understand and analyse the role and impact of the determinants of health in different settings and contexts across time
Critically reflect on your own social, cultural, and professional backgrounds and how this contributes to your understanding of public health practice
Demonstrate skills in written and oral communication, reflection and digital capabilities

assessments.due_date:
Week 2 - Week 13

Public health critical reflection journal are due at 2pm.
assessments.task_description:
As part of the introduction to this course, you will be expected to complete a reflective writing journal engaging with several seminal papers. This will require you to demonstrate the process of critical reflection in relation to the values of public health and the set course readings. You will need to communicate your critical academic reflections in written form.

More information will be available via Blackboard
assessments.submission_guidelines: Further details will be available from the Course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Social analysis of a public health issue
assessments.task_description:
You are a Policy Officer working in a non-government organisation in a location of your choice. Your manager has asked you to present them with a Public Health Social Analysis on a critical public health challenge (the topic will be discussed in class). You will provide your manager with a social analysis of the critical public health challenge as it is affecting a priority population in a particular location.Â 

More information on the set topic and assessment will be available via Blackboard
assessments.submission_guidelines: Further details will be available from the Course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Public health social innovation and elevator pitch
assessments.weighting: <dd>50% Public Health Social Innovation report 30% & Elevator Pitch and script 20% </dd>
assessments.task_description:
You are a Policy Officer working in the same non-government organisation from Assessment 2. Drawing on the key findings from Assessment 2, you have come up with a public health innovation (your big idea) that addresses your critical public health challenge. You have sought permission from your manager to contact your Local Member of Parliament to advocate for the priority population group and to persuade your MP to take a proactive approach to better outcomes (an elevator pitch). In order to provide a comprehensive and well-justified pitch, your manager asks you to summarise your social analysis from assessment 2, outline your public health innovation and project the impact of your big idea.

More information will be available via Blackboard
assessments.submission_guidelines: Further details will be available from the Course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
